children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated for the abrupt appearance of painful skin nodules following an episode of infectious diarrhea. She also reports fever and arthralgia.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome). Individual skin lesions are tender, nonpruritic, brightly erythematous, well-demarcated papules and plaques that appear on the face, neck, and extremities. In addition to the skin eruption, patients typically have high fevers, leukocytosis with a left shift, and elevated inflammatory markers, and often muscle or joint pain.

Sweet syndrome may be idiopathic, but most cases typically develop after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection or in the setting of hematologic abnormalities, particularly myelodysplastic syndrome and myelodysplastic syndrome evolving into acute myeloid leukemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome).
